newsitem.title: CANADA: Corel and Netscape set software alliance.
newsitem.headline: Corel and Netscape set software alliance.

text.p: Corel Corp. and Netscape Communications Corp., seeking to steal some thunder from Microsoft Corp., announced on Monday an alliance to meld office productivity software with enhanced Internet capabilities.

Corel said it licensed Netscape Communicator -- Netscape's new e-mail and browser software -- with the aim of integrating it with Corel's WordPerfect Suite 8 and Corel Office Professional 8. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
The announcement was also designed to take some of the limelight off Microsoft's planned glitzy unveiling of its Office 97 software package on Thursday.
"It (the timing of the announcement) was not an accident," one Netscape official confirmed.

The marriage of Netscape's Internet software suite and Corel's word processor and other software tools is part of a growing marketing trend in which Internet browsing and communications are brought together with other computer applications in a seamless package.

Ottawa-based Corel, along with Lotus software from IBM Corp., has made inroads against Microsoft in the all-important corporate market for so-called productivity software, which includes word processing, spreadd sheets, e-mail and Internet capabilities.

Corel and Mountain View, Calif.-based Netcscape said they would jointly develop the new products, which they hoped to ship later this year. The companies would also undertake joint marketing of the software package.

"Our combined efforts will produce the only desktop productivity suite that is completely open and standards-based, a concept in sharp contrast to the competition," Corel President Michael Cowpland said in a statement.
Corel and has been working with Netscape for some time, offering Netscape Navigator with the WordPerfect Suite and Office Professional since early 1996.
Corel's Cowpland made it clear he was looking for further joint projects with the Internet startup firm Netscape.
"I think we are very keen to be working with Netscape so we will explore all possibilities," Cowpland said in a conference call with journalists and analysts on Monday.

Netscape, which has turned its focus to the corporate "intranet" market, hoped with the Corel deal to capitalize on Corel's success in penetrating Microsoft's hold on the software market, Netscape Vice President Bob Lisbonne said.
